qas.question: What element of a combustion engine does a governor monitor?
What is a governor connected to?
What kinds of adjustments would a governor make?
What would a governor do to a too-fast running engine?

answers.text: reduce the current being applied to the motor

qas.question: What element of a combustion engine doesn't a governor monitor?
What is a governor disconnected from?
What kinds of adjustments would a governor never make?

plausible_answers.text: reduce the current being applied to the motor

qas.question: What would a governor do to a too-slow running engine?

context: Another common application is the control of the throttle of an internal combustion engine in conjunction with an electronic governor. In this usage, the motor works against a return spring to move the throttle in accordance with the output of the governor. The latter monitors engine speed by counting <a0_0><b4_0>electrical pulses<b4_0/><a0_0/> from the ignition system or from a magnetic pickup and, depending on the speed, makes <a2_0><b6_0>small<b6_0/><a2_0/> adjustments to the amount of current applied to the motor. If the engine starts to slow down relative to the desired speed, the current will be increased, the motor will develop more torque, pulling against the <b5_0>return spring<b5_0/> and opening the throttle. Should the engine run too fast, the governor will <a3_0><b7_0>reduce the current being applied to the motor<b7_0/><a3_0/>, causing the <a1_0>return spring<a1_0/> to pull back and close the throttle.
